title: SpaceX Starship
content:
{{Short description|Super heavy-lift reusable launch vehicle}} {{About|SpaceX's Starship in general|its namesake second stage in particular|SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)||}} {{Use American English|date= September 2022}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2022}} {{Infobox rocket | name = Starship | image = StarshipLaunch.jpg | caption = Launch of SpaceX's Starship during its [[SpaceX Starship orbital test flight|first test flight]] | upright = 0.6 | alt = |sites = [[SpaceX Starbase]]
[[Kennedy Space Center]], [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39A|LC-39A]] (planned) | capacities = {{Infobox rocket/payload|to=Q663611}} | stagedata = {{Infobox rocket/stage|stageno=First|type=stage|name=[[SpaceX Super Heavy|Super Heavy]]|qid=Q92727938}} {{Infobox rocket/stage|stageno=Second|type=stage|name=[[SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)|Starship]]|qid=Q56650652}} |launches=1 |success=0|first=20 April 2023|fail=1 |pcost=at least US$3 billion{{efn|Source states cost is the amount invested by SpaceX and doesn't state whether it includes NASA investment}} {{cite web |last1=Sheetz |first1=Micheal |title=SpaceX set to join FAA to fight environmental lawsuit that could delay Starship work |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/05/22/spacex-joining-faa-to-fight-environmental-lawsuit-over-starship.html |website=SpaceX set to join FAA to fight environmental lawsuit that could delay Starship work |publisher=CNBC |access-date=May 24, 2023}}}} '''Starship''' is a [[Super heavy-lift launch vehicle|super heavy-lift]] [[space vehicle]] under development by [[SpaceX]]. At {{Convert|120|m|ft|0|abbr=off}} in height and with a liftoff mass of {{Convert|5000|MT|lb|abbr=off}}, Starship is the largest and most powerful rocket ever flown, surpassing the thrust of the [[Space Launch System|Space Launch System,]] the [[Saturn V]], and the [[N1 (rocket)|N1]].{{Cite web |date=2022-03-18 |title=SLS vs. Starship: How NASA and Elon Musk's giant rocketships compare |url=https://www.inverse.com/innovation/sls-vs-starship |access-date=2023-05-23 |website=Inverse |language=en}} The space vehicle consists of the first-stage [[SpaceX Super Heavy|Super Heavy booster]] and the second-stage spacecraft also named [[SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)|Starship]]. Both stages are powered by [[Raptor rocket engine]]s, which burn [[liquid oxygen]] and liquid [[methane]] propellants in a [[full-flow staged combustion]] power cycle. Both are designed to be [[Reusable launch vehicle|fully reusable]], performing controlled landings on the arms of the [[launch tower]] used to lift the vehicles and reflown within hours. Starship is designed to have a payload capacity of {{Convert|150|t|lb}} to [[low Earth orbit]] in a fully reusable configuration and {{cvt|250|t|lb}} when [[Expendable launch system|expended]].{{cite web |title=Starship |date=5 Feb 2023 |url=https://www.spacex.com/vehicles/starship/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200522145915/https://www.spacex.com/vehicles/starship/ |archive-date=22 May 2020 |access-date=5 Feb 2023 |publisher=SpaceX |quote=Starship will be the world's most powerful launch vehicle ever developed, with the ability to carry up to 149 metric tonnes to Earth orbit reusable, and up to 250 metric tonnes expendable.}} Starship vehicles in low Earth orbit are planned to be [[Orbital propellant depot|refilled with propellant]] launched in tanker Starships to enable transit to higher energy destinations such as [[geosynchronous orbit]], the [[Moon]], and [[Mars]].{{efn|While the space vehicle is named after [[Starship|theoretical spacecraft capable of interstellar travel]], it is not intended to travel beyond our solar system.}} Plans for a heavy-lift vehicle at SpaceX date to 2005, with the earliest concept resembling the modern vehicle announced in 2016. SpaceX's Starship development follows an [[Iterative and incremental development|iterative and incremental approach]] involving frequent, and often [[Destructive testing|destructive]], [[List of SpaceX Starship flight tests|test flights of prototype vehicles]].{{Cite web |author1=Wall |first=Mike |date=2023-04-21 |title=What's next for SpaceX's Starship after its historic flight test? |url=https://www.space.com/spacex-starship-flight-test-whats-next |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230427073926/https://www.space.com/spacex-starship-flight-test-whats-next |archive-date=27 April 2023 |access-date=2023-04-26 |website=[[Space.com]] |language=en}} The first and so far only orbital test flight [[SpaceX Starship orbital test flight|was attempted on 20 April 2023]], when an anomaly caused the vehicle to tumble out of control four minutes after launch. SpaceX activated the [[flight termination system]], which fired the explosive charges but did not destroy the vehicle. Approximately 40 seconds later both stages were destroyed due to increased aerodynamic forces.{{Cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |date=2023-04-30 |title=SpaceX Rocket Struggled to Self-Destruct as It Spun Out of Control |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/29/science/elon-musk-spacex-starship.html |access-date=2023-05-13 |issn=0362-4331}} After the test, the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) grounded the launch program pending results of a standard "mishap investigation".{{Cite web |last=Kolodny |first=Lora |title=SpaceX Starship explosion spread particulate matter for miles |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/04/24/spacex-starship-explosion-spread-particulate-matter-for-miles.html |access-date=2023-04-27 |website=CNBC |language=en |archive-date=25 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230425045623/https://www.cnbc.com/2023/04/24/spacex-starship-explosion-spread-particulate-matter-for-miles.html |url-status=live }} SpaceX intends Starship to become its primary space vehicle, superseding the [[Falcon 9]] and [[Falcon Heavy]] launch vehicles as well as the [[SpaceX Dragon 2|Dragon 2]] spacecraft currently used as part of [[NASA]]'s [[Commercial Crew Program|commercial crew program]] to the [[International Space Station]]. Starship is often coupled with [[SpaceX Mars program|the company's Mars ambitions]]. Planned Starship flights include the development of SpaceX's [[Starlink]] internet constellation, crewed flights under the [[Polaris program|Polaris]] and [[DearMoon project|dearMoon]] programs, and a [[Artemis 3|crewed lunar landing]] with a [[Starship HLS|modified Starship spacecraft]] under the [[Artemis program]]. == History == Starting with a 2012 announcement of plans to develop a rocket with substantially greater capabilities than SpaceX's existing Falcon 9—underpinned by the ambition to enable [[exploration of Mars|human exploration]] and [[colonization of Mars|settlement of Mars]]—the company created a succession of designs for such a vehicle, under various names (''Mars Colonial Transporter'', ''Interplanetary Transport System'', ''BFR'') leading up to a 2019 adoption of a stainless-steel body design, which is also when the name changed to the current ''Starship''. SpaceX has since been applying the [[iterative design]] methodology, using intensive tests on a series of rocket [[prototype]]s.{{Cite web |author1=Wall |first=Mike |date=2023-04-21 |title=What's next for SpaceX's Starship after its historic flight test? |url=https://www.space.com/spacex-starship-flight-test-whats-next |access-date=2023-04-26 |website=[[Space.com]] |language=en |archive-date=27 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230427073926/https://www.space.com/spacex-starship-flight-test-whats-next |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=21 February 2020 |title=SpaceX pushing iterative design process, accepting failure to go fast |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/02/elon-musk-says-spacex-driving-toward-orbital-starship-flight-in-2020/ |access-date=5 July 2022 |website=[[Ars Technica]] |language=en-us |archive-date=25 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201225115453/https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/02/elon-musk-says-spacex-driving-toward-orbital-starship-flight-in-2020/ |url-status=live }}{{Cite web |last=Reichhardt |first=Tony |date=14 December 2021 |title=Marsliner |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/air-space-magazine/marsliner-180979371/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220506104518/https://www.smithsonianmag.com/air-space-magazine/marsliner-180979371/ |archive-date=6 May 2022 |access-date=10 June 2022 |website=[[Air & Space/Smithsonian]] |url-status=live |language=en}} The first prototype, Starhopper, performed several [[static fire]]s and low-altitude flights.{{cite web |last=Harwood|first=William |date=27 August 2019|title=SpaceX launches "Starhopper" on dramatic test flight|publisher=[[CBS News]] |language=en-US |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/spacex-launches-starhopper-dramatic-test-flight-today-2019-08-27/|url-status=live|access-date=14 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201108000728/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/spacex-launches-starhopper-dramatic-test-flight-today-2019-08-27/|archive-date=8 November 2020}} Seven of Starship's upper-stage prototypes were flight tested between August 2020 and May 2021. The last of the seven, a full-size ''[[SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)#SN15 - SN19|Starship SN15]]'', successfully landed after reaching an altitude of {{convert|10|km|mi|sp=us}}. A [[SpaceX Starship orbital test flight|full-scale orbital test flight]] of the rocket took place on April 20, 2023.{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=2023-04-14 |title=Green light go: SpaceX receives a launch license from the FAA for Starship |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2023/04/green-light-go-spacex-receives-a-launch-license-from-the-faa-for-starship/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230414234532/https://arstechnica.com/science/2023/04/green-light-go-spacex-receives-a-launch-license-from-the-faa-for-starship/ |archive-date=14 April 2023 |access-date=2023-04-15 |website=[[Ars Technica]] |language=en-us}} === Early design proposals === {{Further|SpaceX Mars program}} In 2007, Elon Musk publicly stated that he hopes to enable the exploration and settlement of Mars through SpaceX.{{cite news|last=Hoffman|first=Carl|title=Elon Musk Is Betting His Fortune on a Mission Beyond Earth's Orbit|url=https://www.wired.com/science/space/magazine/15-06/ff_space_musk?currentPage=all|access-date=14 March 2014|newspaper=Wired Magazine|date=22 May 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114052527/http://www.wired.com/science/space/magazine/15-06/ff_space_musk?currentPage=all|archive-date=14 November 2012|url-status=live}}{{cite news|title=Elon Musk: I'll Put a Man on Mars in 10 Years |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/video/asset/elon-musk-ill-put-a-man-on-mars-in-10-years-2011-04-22/CCF1FC62-BB0D-4561-938C-DF0DEFAD15BA#!CCF1FC62-BB0D-4561-938C-DF0DEFAD15BA |newspaper=Market Watch |date=22 April 2011 |location=New York |access-date=1 December 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902234053/http://www.marketwatch.com/video/asset/elon-musk-ill-put-a-man-on-mars-in-10-years-2011-04-22/CCF1FC62-BB0D-4561-938C-DF0DEFAD15BA |url-status=live |archive-date=2 September 2011 }} SpaceX began developing the [[Raptor (rocket engine family)|Raptor rocket engine]] (the engine used in Starship) before 2014. From 2011 to 2014, Musk made various statements expressing his hope that SpaceX would send humans to Mars in the 2020s to 2030s.{{cite news |url=http://news.discovery.com/space/alien-life-exoplanets/mars-colony-spacex-121126.htm |title=Huge Mars Colony Eyed by SpaceX Founder |date=13 December 2012 |access-date=25 September 2016 |publisher=Discovery News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115083758/http://news.discovery.com/space/alien-life-exoplanets/mars-colony-spacex-121126.htm |archive-date=15 November 2014 |url-status=live }}{{cite news |last=Carroll |first=Rory |title=Elon Musk's mission to Mars |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/jul/17/elon-musk-mission-mars-spacex |access-date=25 September 2016 |newspaper=TheGuardian |date=17 July 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108024353/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/jul/17/elon-musk-mission-mars-spacex |archive-date=8 January 2014 |url-status=live }}{{cite news |last=Messier |first=Doug |title=Elon Musk Talks ISS Flights, Vladimir Putin and Mars |access-date=25 September 2016 |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2014/02/05/elon-musk-interview-2/ |newspaper=Parabolic Arc |date=5 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180916164003/http://www.parabolicarc.com/2014/02/05/elon-musk-interview-2/ |archive-date=16 September 2018 |url-status=live }} ==== Mars Colonial Transporter ==== In October 2012, Musk made the first public articulation of plans to develop a fully reusable rocket system with substantially greater capabilities than SpaceX's existing Falcon 9.{{cite news |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/spacex-aims-big-with-massive-new-rocket-377687/ |title=SpaceX aims big with massive new rocket |date=15 October 2012 |first=Zach |last=Rosenberg |access-date=25 September 2016 |publisher=Flight Global |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703043710/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/spacex-aims-big-with-massive-new-rocket-377687/ |archive-date=3 July 2015 |url-status=live }} This new launch vehicle was intended to be part of the company's Mars system architecture, then known as "MCT" or [[SpaceX Mars program|Mars Colonial Transporter/Mass Cargo Transport]]. According to SpaceX, the MCT system would include [[reusable launch vehicle|reusable]] [[rocket engine]]s, [[launch vehicle]]s and [[space capsule]]s that would enable [[human mission to Mars|transportation of humans to Mars]] and back to [[Earth]]. SpaceX COO [[Gwynne Shotwell]] gave a potential payload range between 150-200 tonnes to [[low Earth orbit]] for the planned rocket. According to SpaceX, the MCT was to be "going to be much bigger [than Falcon 9]".{{cite news |last=Coppinger |first=Rod |title=Huge Mars Colony Eyed by SpaceX Founder Elon Musk |url=http://www.space.com/18596-mars-colony-spacex-elon-musk.html |access-date=25 September 2016 |newspaper=Space.com |date=23 November 2012 |quote=''an evolution of SpaceX's Falcon 9 booster ... much bigger [than Falcon 9], but I don’t think we’re quite ready to state the payload. We’ll speak about that next year. ... Vertical landing is an extremely important breakthrough — extreme, rapid reusability.'' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130628154029/http://www.space.com/18596-mars-colony-spacex-elon-musk.html |archive-date=28 June 2013 |url-status=live }} In February 2014, the planned principal payload for the MCT was announced to be a large [[Interplanetary spaceflight|interplanetary spacecraft]], designed to carry up to {{convert|100|tonne|lb}} of passengers and cargo.{{cite news |last1=Heath |first1=Chris |date=12 December 2015 |title=How Elon Musk Plans on Reinventing the World (and Mars) |work=GQ |url=https://www.gq.com/story/elon-musk-mars-spacex-tesla-interview |url-status=live |access-date=25 September 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151212142443/http://www.gq.com/story/elon-musk-mars-spacex-tesla-interview |archive-date=12 December 2015}} According to SpaceX engine development head [[Tom Mueller]], SpaceX would use nine [[SpaceX Raptor|Raptor]] engines on a single craft.{{cite news |last=Nellis |first=Stephen |date=19 February 2014 |title=SpaceX's propulsion chief elevates crowd in Santa Barbara |newspaper=Pacific Coast Business Times |url=http://www.pacbiztimes.com/2014/02/19/spacexs-propulsion-chief-elevates-crowd-in-santa-barbara// |url-status=live |access-date=25 September 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160926231416/http://www.pacbiztimes.com/2014/02/19/spacexs-propulsion-chief-elevates-crowd-in-santa-barbara |archive-date=26 September 2016}} The rocket would be at least {{convert|10|m|sp=us}} in diameter and was expected to have up to three cores totaling at least 27 engines.{{cite news |last=Belluscio |first=Alejandro G. |title=SpaceX advances drive for Mars rocket via Raptor power |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/03/spacex-advances-drive-mars-rocket-raptor-power/ |access-date=25 September 2016 |newspaper=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=7 March 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150911235533/http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/03/spacex-advances-drive-mars-rocket-raptor-power/ |archive-date=11 September 2015 |url-status=live }} ==== Interplanetary Transport System ==== In 2016, Musk changed the name of the Mars Colonial Transporter system to the '''Interplanetary Transport System''' ('''ITS'''), as he intended for the system to be capable of traveling beyond Mars.{{cite news |last=Berger |first=Eric |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/09/spacexs-interplanetary-transport-system-will-go-well-beyond-mars/ |title=Elon Musk scales up his ambitions, considering going "well beyond" Mars |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=18 September 2016 |access-date=19 September 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920000810/http://arstechnica.com/science/2016/09/spacexs-interplanetary-transport-system-will-go-well-beyond-mars/ |archive-date=20 September 2016 |url-status=live }} That same year he provided more details about the space mission architecture, launch vehicle, spacecraft, and Raptor engines. The first test firing of a Raptor engine on a test stand took place in September 2016.{{cite news |last=Belluscio |first=Alejandro G. |title=ITS Propulsion – The evolution of the SpaceX Raptor engine |work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |date=3 October 2016 |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/10/its-propulsion-evolution-raptor-engine/ |access-date=3 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181122165306/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/10/its-propulsion-evolution-raptor-engine/ |archive-date=22 November 2018 |url-status=live }}{{cite conference |title=2016 StartmeupHK Venture Forum - Elon Musk on Entrepreneurship and Innovation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pIRqB5iqWA8 |conference=StartmeupHK Venture Forum--2016 |conference-url=http://www.startmeup.hk/en/startmeuphk-festival-2016/forum/ |publisher=Invest Hong Kong |place=via InvestHK YouTube channel |date=26 January 2016 |access-date=28 January 2016 |quote=(SpaceX discussion at 30:15-31:40) ''We'll have the next generation rocket and spacecraft, beyond the Falcon and Dragon series ... I'm hoping to describe that architecture later this year at the International Astronautical Congress. which is the big international space event every year. ... first flights to Mars? we're hoping to do that in around 2025 ... nine years from now or thereabouts.'' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128220018/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pIRqB5iqWA8 |archive-date=28 January 2016 |url-status=live }} In October 2016, Musk indicated that the initial tank test article, made out of [[carbon-fiber|carbon]] [[pre-preg]], and built with no sealing liner, had performed well in cryogenic fluid testing. A pressure test at about 2/3 of the design burst pressure was completed in November 2016.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com.au/spacex-carbon-fiber-fuel-tank-ocean-ship-test-2016-11?r=US&IR=T|title=The 'trickiest' part of Elon Musk's Mars spaceship -- a giant black orb -- just passed a critical test|last=Mosher|first=Dave|date=17 November 2016|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=18 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161117211129/http://www.businessinsider.com.au/spacex-carbon-fiber-fuel-tank-ocean-ship-test-2016-11?r=US&IR=T|archive-date=17 November 2016|url-status=live}} In July 2017, Musk indicated that the architecture design had evolved since 2016 in order to support commercial transport via Earth-orbit and cislunar launches.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BqvBhhTtUm4?t=852|title=Elon Musk, ISS R&D Conference|date=19 July 2017|people=Elon Musk|location=ISS R&D Conference, Washington DC, USA|time=49:48–51:35|access-date=13 September 2017|quote=the updated version of the Mars architecture: Because it has evolved quite a bit since that last talk. ... The key thing that I figured out is how do you pay for it? If we downsize the Mars vehicle, make it capable of doing Earth-orbit activity as well as Mars activity, maybe we can pay for it by using it for Earth-orbit activity. That is one of the key elements in the new architecture. It is similar to what was shown at IAC, but a little bit smaller. Still big, but this one has a shot at being real on the economic front.|medium=video|via=YouTube}} The ITS stack was to be composed of two stages, both powered by Raptor engines. A first stage booster, and a second stage that was to be either an "Interplanetary Spaceship" for crewed transport or an "ITS tanker" for orbital refueling. By that point, Raptor was a [[rocket engine]] in a [[full flow staged combustion cycle]], with [[liquid methane]] fuel and [[liquid oxygen]] oxidizer.{{cite news |last1=Bergin |first1=Chris |title=Falcon Heavy enabler for Dragon solar system explorer |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/05/falcon-heavy-dragon-solar-system-explorer/ |access-date=12 May 2015 |work=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=11 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150513211939/http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/05/falcon-heavy-dragon-solar-system-explorer/ |archive-date=13 May 2015 |url-status=live }} Both propellants would enter the [[combustion chamber]] in the [[gas phase]]. A bleed-off of the high-pressure gas would provide autogenous pressurization of the propellant tanks, eliminating the Falcon 9's problematic high-pressure [[helium]] pressurization system.{{cite news |last=Bergin |first=Chris |date=27 September 2016 |title=SpaceX reveals ITS Mars game changer via colonization plan |work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/09/spacex-reveals-mars-game-changer-colonization-plan/ |url-status=live |access-date=27 September 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160928154300/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/09/spacex-reveals-mars-game-changer-colonization-plan/ |archive-date=28 September 2016}} The overall launch vehicle height, (first and second stages), was to be {{cvt|122|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.{{cite tweet |last=Musk |first=Elon |author-link=Elon Musk |user=elonmusk |number=780831628104966144 |date=27 September 2016 |title=12m rocket booster diameter, 17m spaceship diameter, 122 m stack height |language=en |access-date=22 August 2021}} Both stages were to have been constructed of [[carbon fiber]], including the [[Cryogenic fuel|cryogenic propellant]] tanks, a major change for SpaceX from the Falcon 9's [[aluminum-lithium alloy]] tank and structure material. Both stages were to be fully reusable and were to land vertically. Gross liftoff mass was to be {{convert|10500|t|st|abbr=on}} at a lift-off [[thrust]] of {{convert|128|MN|lbf}}. ITS was planned to be able to carry a payload to [[low Earth orbit]] of {{convert|550|tonne|lbs}} in [[expendable rocket|expendable-mode]] and {{convert|300|tonne|lbs}} in [[reusable launch vehicle|reusable mode]].{{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/making_life_multiplanetary_2016.pdf |publisher=[[SpaceX]] |title=Making Humans a Multiplanetary Species |date=27 September 2016 |access-date=10 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171120185053/http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/making_life_multiplanetary_2016.pdf |archive-date=20 November 2017 |url-status=live }} [[File:Interplanetary Transport System (29937260776).jpg|thumb|2016 artist's concept of the ITS booster returning to the launch pad|left|upright=1.5]] The '''ITS booster''' was to be a {{convert|12|m|ft|0|abbr=on|adj=mid|-diameter}}, {{convert|77.5|m|ft|0|abbr=on|adj=mid|-high}}, reusable first stage powered by 42 engines, each producing {{convert|3024|kN|lbf}} of [[thrust]]. Total booster thrust would have been about {{convert|128|MN|lbf|abbr=on}} at liftoff, several times the {{convert|8000000|lbf|MN|order=flip|abbr=on}} thrust of the [[Saturn V]]. The engine configuration included 21 engines in an outer ring and 14 in an inner ring. The center cluster of seven engines was to be [[gimbaled thrust|gimbaled]] for directional control, although some directional control was to be performed via [[Differential engine thrust|differential thrust]] on the fixed engines. Thrust on each engine was aimed to [[rocket engine throttling|vary]] between 20 and 100 percent of rated thrust.The main propellants, in gaseous phase, were to also power the [[Reaction control system|reaction control thrusters]]. These thrusters were intended to control booster orientation in space and improve accuracy during landing. The design goal was to achieve a [[separation event|separation]] velocity of about {{convert|8650|km/h|abbr=on}} while retaining about 7% of the initial propellant to achieve a [[VTVL|vertical landing]] at the launch pad.{{cite news |url= http://www.spaceflightinsider.com/organizations/space-exploration-technologies/elon-musk-shows-off-interplanetary-transport-system/ |title= Elon Musk Shows Off Interplanetary Transport System |publisher= Spaceflight Insider |last= Richardson |first= Derek |date= 27 September 2016 |access-date= 3 October 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161001225649/http://www.spaceflightinsider.com/organizations/space-exploration-technologies/elon-musk-shows-off-interplanetary-transport-system/ |archive-date= 1 October 2016 |url-status= live }}{{cite news |last=Berger |first=Eric |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/09/musks-mars-moment-audacity-madness-brilliance-or-maybe-all-three/ |title=Musk's Mars moment: Audacity, madness, brilliance—or maybe all three |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=28 September 2016 |access-date=13 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013144816/http://arstechnica.com/science/2016/09/musks-mars-moment-audacity-madness-brilliance-or-maybe-all-three/ |archive-date=13 October 2016 |url-status=live }}The design called for [[grid fin]]s to guide the booster during [[Atmospheric entry|atmospheric reentry]]. The booster return flights were expected to encounter loads lower than the Falcon 9, principally because the ITS would have both a lower mass ratio and a lower density.{{cite news |last=Boyle |first=Alan |date=23 October 2016 |title=SpaceX's Elon Musk geeks out over Mars interplanetary transport plan on Reddit |work=[[GeekWire]] |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2016/spacex-elon-musk-geeks-out-mars-reddit/ |url-status=live |access-date=24 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024013759/http://www.geekwire.com/2016/spacex-elon-musk-geeks-out-mars-reddit/ |archive-date=24 October 2016}} The booster was to be designed for 20 ''g'' nominal loads, and possibly as high as 30–40 ''g''. In contrast to the landing approach used on SpaceX's mid-2010s reusable rocket first stages—either a large, flat concrete pad or [[downrange]] [[Autonomous spaceport drone ship|floating landing platform]], the ITS booster was to designed to land on the launch mount itself, for immediate refueling and relaunch. [[File:ITS Interplanetary Spaceship, in orbit near the rings of Saturn.jpg|thumb|2016 artist concept of the ITS Interplanetary Spaceship, in orbit near the rings of Saturn]] The '''ITS second stage''' was planned to be used for long-duration spaceflight, instead of solely being used for reaching orbit. The two proposed variants aimed to be reusable. * The '''Interplanetary Spaceship''', a large passenger-carrying [[spacecraft]] design proposed in September 2016. The ship would have operated as a second-stage and [[Beyond Earth orbit|interplanetary]] [[space transport|transport]] vehicle for cargo and passengers. It aimed to transport up to {{convert|450|tonne|lbs}} per trip to Mars following refueling in Earth orbit. Its three sea-level Raptor engines were designed to be used for maneuvering, descent, landing, and initial ascent from the Mars surface. * The '''ITS tanker''', a second stage [[propellant tanker]] variant design. It aimed to transport up to {{convert|380|tonne|lbs}} of propellants to [[low Earth orbit]] to refuel Interplanetary Spaceships. After refueling operations, it was to land and be prepared for another flight. ==== BFR ==== In September 2017, at the 68th annual meeting of the [[International Astronautical Congress]], Musk announced a new launch vehicle calling it the '''BFR''', again changing the name, though stating that the name was temporary.{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tdUX3ypDVwI |title=Making Life Multiplanetary |date=29 September 2017 |publisher=[[SpaceX]] |access-date=22 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210819035735/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tdUX3ypDVwI |archive-date=19 August 2021 |url-status=live |via=[[YouTube]]}} The acronym was alternatively stated as standing for '''Big Falcon Rocket''' or '''Big Fucking Rocket''', a tongue-in-cheek reference to the BFG from the [[Doom (franchise)|Doom video game series]]. Its goal was to send two cargo missions to Mars in 2022, with the goal to "confirm water resources and identify hazards" while deploying "power, mining, and life support infrastructure" for future flights. This would be followed by four ships in 2024, two crewed BFR spaceships plus two cargo-only ships carrying equipment and supplies for a propellant plant. The design balanced objectives such as payload mass, landing capabilities, and reliability. The initial design showed the ship with six Raptor engines (two sea-level, four vacuum) down from nine in the previous ITS design. [[File:BFR at stage separation 2-2018.jpg|thumb|left|2018 artist's conception of the redesigned BFR/Starship at stage separation]] By September 2017, Raptors had been test-fired for a combined total of 20 minutes across 42 test cycles. The longest test was 100 seconds, limited by the size of the propellant tanks. The test engine operated at {{convert|20|MPa|bar psi|lk=in|abbr=on}}. The flight engine aimed for {{convert|25|MPa|bar psi|lk=in|abbr=on}}, on the way to {{convert|30|MPa|bar psi|lk=in|abbr=on}} in later iterations. In November 2017, [[Gwynne Shotwell|Shotwell]] indicated that about half of all development work on BFR was focused on the engine.{{cite news |first=Caleb |last=Henry |url=http://spacenews.com/spacex-aims-to-follow-a-banner-year-with-an-even-faster-2018-launch-cadence/ |title=SpaceX aims to follow a banner year with an even faster 2018 launch cadence |work=[[SpaceNews]] |date=21 November 2017 |access-date=15 January 2018 |quote=Shotwell estimated that around 50 percent of the work on BFR is focused on the Raptor engines.}} SpaceX looked for manufacturing sites in [[California]], [[Texas]], [[Louisiana]],{{cite news|last=Masunaga|first=Samantha|date=19 April 2018|title=SpaceX gets approval to develop its BFR rocket and spaceship at Port of Los Angeles|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-spacex-port-la-20180419-story.html|url-status=live|access-date=21 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180421211034/http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-spacex-port-la-20180419-story.html|archive-date=21 April 2018}} and [[Florida]].{{cite AV media|url=http://portofla.granicus.com/MediaPlayer.php?view_id=9&clip_id=1148|title=Port Authority of Los Angeles, Regular Board Meeting|date=19 April 2018|people=Michael DiBernardo|publisher=LA: The Port of Los Angeles|time=35:36|access-date=21 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180422202551/http://portofla.granicus.com/MediaPlayer.php?view_id=9&clip_id=1148|archive-date=22 April 2018|url-status=live|medium=video|via=YouTube}} By September 2017, SpaceX had started building launch vehicle components: "The tooling for the main tanks has been ordered, the facility is being built, we will start construction of the first ship [in the second quarter of 2018.]" By early 2018, the first carbon composite prototype ship was under construction, and SpaceX had begun building a new production facility at the [[Port of Los Angeles]].{{cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |url=http://spacenews.com/musk-reiterates-plans-for-testing-bfr/ |title=Musk reiterates plans for testing BFR |work=[[SpaceNews]] |date=12 March 2018 |access-date=15 March 2018 |quote=Construction of the first prototype spaceship is in progress. 'We're actually building that ship right now,' he said. 'I think we'll probably be able to do short flights, short sort of up-and-down flights, probably sometime in the first half of next year.'}} In March, SpaceX announced that it would manufacture its launch vehicle and spaceship at a new facility on Seaside Drive at the port.{{cite news|last=Berger|first=Eric|date=19 March 2018|title=SpaceX indicates it will manufacture the BFR rocket in Los Angeles|work=[[Ars Technica]]|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/03/spacex-indicates-it-will-manufacture-the-bfr-rocket-in-los-angeles/|url-status=live|access-date=21 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180321004606/https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/03/spacex-indicates-it-will-manufacture-the-bfr-rocket-in-los-angeles/|archive-date=21 March 2018}}{{cite web|date=11 October 2017|title=Fireside Chat with SpaceX President Gwynne Shotwell|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/jurvetson/37659376821|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190405042216/https://www.flickr.com/photos/jurvetson/37659376821/|archive-date=5 April 2019|access-date=7 March 2018|publisher=Flickr.com}}{{cite magazine|last=Seemangal|first=Robin|date=1 February 2018|title=SpaceX Gears Up to Finally, Actually Launch the Falcon Heavy|magazine=Wired|url=https://www.wired.com/story/spacex-gears-up-to-finally-actually-launch-the-falcon-heavy/|url-status=live|access-date=7 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225062849/https://www.wired.com/story/spacex-gears-up-to-finally-actually-launch-the-falcon-heavy/|archive-date=25 February 2018|quote=SpaceX is actively considering expanding its San Pedro, California facility to begin manufacturing its interplanetary spacecraft. This would allow SpaceX to easily shift personnel from headquarters in Hawthorne.}} By May, about 40 SpaceX employees were working on the BFR. SpaceX planned to transport the launch vehicle by [[barge]], through the [[Panama Canal]], to [[Cape Canaveral]] for launch. Since then the company has pivoted and terminated the agreements to do this. In August 2018, the head of the US Air Force [[Air Mobility Command]] expressed interest in the ability of the BFR to move up to {{cvt|150|tonne|lb}} of cargo anywhere in the world in under 30 minutes, for "less than the cost of a [[Lockheed C-5 Galaxy|C-5]]".{{cite news |last=Insinnia|first=Valerie |url=https://www.defensenews.com/space/2018/08/02/one-possible-job-for-spacexs-bfr-taking-the-air-forces-cargo-in-and-out-of-space/ |title=One possible job for SpaceX's BFR rocket? Taking the Air Force's cargo in and out of space. |work=[[DefenseNews]] |date=2 August 2018 |access-date=9 June 2019 }}[https://dod.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1591975/air-mobility-command-chief-looks-toward-supplying-forces-from-space/ Air Mobility Command Chief Looks Toward Supplying Forces From Space] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190609111931/https://dod.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1591975/air-mobility-command-chief-looks-toward-supplying-forces-from-space/ |date=9 June 2019 }}, US Department of Defense, 2 August 2018. The BFR was designed to be {{convert|106|m|ft|sp=us}} tall, {{convert|9|m|ft|sp=us}} in diameter, and made of [[carbon fiber]].{{cite journal|last1=Musk|first1=Elon|date=1 March 2018|title=Making Life Multi-Planetary|journal=New Space|volume=6|issue=1|pages=2–11|bibcode=2018NewSp...6....2M|doi=10.1089/space.2018.29013.emu}}{{cite news | first=Jeff | last=Foust | url=https://spacenews.com/musk-unveils-revised-version-of-giant-interplanetary-launch-system/ | title=Musk unveils revised version of giant interplanetary launch system | work=[[SpaceNews]] | date=29 September 2017 | access-date=1 October 2017}} The upper stage, known as Big Falcon Ship (BFS), included a small [[delta wing]] at the rear end with [[split flap]]s for [[Aircraft principal axes|pitch and roll control]]. The delta wing and split flaps were said to expand the [[flight envelope]] to allow the ship to land in a variety of [[gas density|atmospheric densities]] (vacuum, thin, or heavy atmosphere) with a wide range of payloads.{{rp|18:05–19:25}} The BFS originally had six Raptor engines, with four vacuum and two sea-level. By late 2017, SpaceX added a third sea-level engine (totaling 7) to allow greater Earth-to-Earth payload landings and still ensure capability if one of the engines fails.{{cite news | first=Jeff | last=Foust | url=http://spacenews.com/musk-offers-more-technical-details-on-bfr-system/ | title=Musk offers more technical details on BFR system | work=[[SpaceNews]] | date=15 October 2017 | access-date=27 May 2019 | quote=[Musk] added that, since the presentation last month, SpaceX has revised the design of the BFR spaceship to add a "medium area ratio" Raptor engine to its original complement of two engines with sea-level nozzles and four with vacuum nozzles. That additional engine helps enable that engine-out capability ... and will "allow landings with higher payload mass for the Earth to Earth transport function."}}{{Efn|"Still ensuring capability if one of the engine fails" is what the source means by "engine-out capability".}} Three BFS versions were described: BFS cargo, BFS tanker, and BFS crew. The cargo version was to be used to reach Earth orbit as well as carry cargo to the Moon or Mars. After refueling in an elliptical Earth orbit, BFS was designed to eventually be able to land on the Moon and return to Earth without another refueling.{{rp|31:50}} The BFR also aimed to carry passengers/cargo in Earth-to-Earth transport, delivering its payload anywhere within 90 minutes. === Redesign as Starship and Super Heavy and switch to stainless steel === In 2018 Musk announced a planned 2023 lunar circumnavigation mission (#[[dearMoon project|''dearMoon'' project]]){{cite magazine|date=18 September 2018|title=Elon Musk Says SpaceX Will Send Yusaku Maezawa (and Artists!) to the Moon|magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|url=https://www.wired.com/story/spacex-will-send-yusaku-maezawa-and-artists-to-the-moon/|url-status=live|access-date=27 May 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190716034529/https://www.wired.com/story/spacex-will-send-yusaku-maezawa-and-artists-to-the-moon/|archive-date=16 July 2019}} and showed a redesigned BFR concept with three rear fins and two front canard fins, replacing the previous delta wing and split flaps. The revised design used seven Raptor engines and had two small actuating [[Canard (aeronautics)|canard]] fins near the nose, and three large fins at the base, two of which would actuate, with all three serving as landing legs.{{cite news|first=Eric|last=Ralph|date=14 September 2018|title=SpaceX has signed a private passenger for the first BFR launch around the Moon|url=https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-private-passenger-bfr-moon-mission/|url-status=live|access-date=14 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180914132048/https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-private-passenger-bfr-moon-mission/|archive-date=14 September 2018}}{{Multiple images | image2 = Starship sn5.jpg | image1 = SpaceX Starhopper.jpg | Perrow = 2 | total_width = 400 | alt2 = Crane hooking onto a steel vessel body | alt1 = Short steel rocket with its fins touching the ground | caption2 = A crane lifting Starship SN5, August 2020 | caption1 = Starhopper under construction, March 2019 | direction = horizontal | align }} The two major parts were renamed to [[SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)|Starship (second stage)]] and [[Super Heavy (rocket stage)|Super Heavy]] (booster stage).{{cite news|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2018/goodbye-bfr-hello-starship-elon-musk-gives-classic-name-mars-spaceship/|title=Goodbye, BFR … hello, Starship: Elon Musk gives a classic name to his Mars spaceship|last=Boyle|first=Alan|date=19 November 2018|work=[[GeekWire]]|access-date=22 November 2018|quote=''Starship is the spaceship/upper stage & Super Heavy is the rocket booster needed to escape Earth's deep gravity well (not needed for other planets or moons)''|author-link=Alan Boyle|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181122215524/https://www.geekwire.com/2018/goodbye-bfr-hello-starship-elon-musk-gives-classic-name-mars-spaceship/|archive-date=22 November 2018|url-status=live}} In 2019, SpaceX began to refer to the Starship / Super Heavy combination as the Starship system.{{cite web|title=Starship|url=https://www.spacex.com/starship|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190930163150/https://www.spacex.com/starship|archive-date=30 September 2019|access-date=30 September 2019|publisher=SpaceX}}{{cite web|url=https://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/starship_users_guide_v1.pdf |title=Starship Users Guide, Revision 1.0, March 2020 |publisher=SpaceX |date=March 2020 |access-date=18 May 2020 |quote=SpaceX's Starship system represents a fully reusable transportation system designed to service Earth orbit needs as well as missions to the Moon and Mars. This two-stage vehicle – composed of the Super Heavy rocket (booster) and Starship (spacecraft) |archive-date=2 April 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200402122214/https://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/starship_users_guide_v1.pdf|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last=berger|first=Eric|date=5 March 2020|title=Inside Elon Musk's plan to build one Starship a week and settle Mars|publisher=Ars Technica|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/03/inside-elon-musks-plan-to-build-one-starship-a-week-and-settle-mars/|url-status=live|access-date=6 March 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200305204228/https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/03/inside-elon-musks-plan-to-build-one-starship-a-week-and-settle-mars/|archive-date=5 March 2020|quote=''Musk tackles the hardest engineering problems first. For Mars, there will be so many logistical things to make it all work, from power on the surface to scratching out a living to adapting to its extreme climate. But Musk believes that the initial, hardest step is building a reusable, orbital Starship to get people and tons of stuff to Mars. So he is focused on that''.}}{{cite news |last=Berger|first=Eric |url=https://arstechnica.com/features/2019/09/after-starship-unveiling-mars-seems-a-little-closer/ |title=Elon Musk, Man of Steel, reveals his stainless Starship|publisher=Ars Technica|date=29 September 2019|access-date=30 September 2019 |archive-date=28 December 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191228174451/https://arstechnica.com/features/2019/09/after-starship-unveiling-mars-seems-a-little-closer/ |url-status=live }} In September 2019, Musk further detailed the lower-stage booster, the upper-stage's method of controlling its descent, the heat shield, orbital refueling capacity, and potential destinations besides Mars.{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=Jackson|date=29 September 2019|title=Elon Musk says SpaceX Starship rocket could reach orbit within 6 months|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/elon-musk-says-spacex-starship-rocket-could-reach-orbit-within-six-months/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211215091103/https://www.cnet.com/news/elon-musk-says-spacex-starship-rocket-could-reach-orbit-within-six-months/|archive-date=15 December 2021|access-date=15 December 2021|publisher=[[CNET]]|language=en}} The aft flaps on the spacecraft were reduced from three to two. Starship's structural material was changed from carbon composites to stainless steel.{{cite web |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |date=29 September 2019 |title=SpaceX Unveils Silvery Vision to Mars: 'It's an I.C.B.M. That Lands' |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/29/science/elon-musk-spacex-starship.html |url-status=live |url-access=limited |access-date=16 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211030080406/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/29/science/elon-musk-spacex-starship.html |archive-date=30 October 2021}} Musk cited the low cost and ease of manufacture, increased strength of stainless steel at [[Cryogenic rocket engine|cryogenic temperatures]], as well as its ability to withstand high heat, as the reasons for the design change.{{cite web |last1=D'Agostino |first1=Ryan |title=Elon Musk: Why I'm Building the Starship out of Stainless Steel |url=https://www.popularmechanics.com/space/rockets/a25953663/elon-musk-spacex-bfr-stainless-steel/ |website=popularmechanics.com |publisher=[[Popular Mechanics]] |access-date=22 January 2019 |language=en |date=22 January 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190122161633/https://www.popularmechanics.com/space/rockets/a25953663/elon-musk-spacex-bfr-stainless-steel/ |archive-date=22 January 2019 |url-status=live }} The high temperature at which 300-series steel transitions to [[Plasticity (physics)|plastic deformation]] would eliminate the need for a heat shield on Starship's space-facing side, while the much hotter Earth-facing side would be cooled by allowing fuel or water to bleed through micropores in a double-wall stainless steel skin, removing heat by [[evaporation]]. In 2019, the design reverted to six Raptor engines, with three [[Rocket engine nozzle#Atmospheric use|optimized for sea-level]] and three [[Rocket engine nozzle#Vacuum use|optimized for vacuum]].{{cite tweet |first=Elon |last=Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1131433322276483072 |title=3 sea level optimized Raptors, 3 vacuum optimized Raptors (big nozzle)}} Initial Super Heavy test flights would use fewer engines, perhaps about 20.{{cite tweet |number=1131625229367693312 |user=elonmusk |title=First flights would have fewer, so as to risk less loss of hardware. Probably around 20.|first=Elon|last=Musk}} Later in 2019 Musk stated that Starship was expected to have empty mass of {{cvt|120|tonne|kg lb|order=out}} and be able to initially transport a payload of {{cvt|100|tonne|kg lb|order=out}}, growing to {{cvt|150|tonne|kg lb|order=out}} over time. Musk hinted at an expendable variant that could place 250 tonnes into low orbit.{{cite tweet |last=Musk |first=Elon |author-link=Elon Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1423677217133957127 |date=6 August 2021 |title=@NASASpaceflight @BBCAmos Over time, we might get orbital payload up to ~150 tons with full reusabity. If Starship then launched as an expendable, payload would be ~250 tons. What isn’t obvious from this chart is that Starship/Super Heavy is much denser than Saturn V. |language=en |access-date=22 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210814082555/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1423677217133957127 |archive-date=14 August 2021 |url-status=live}}{{failed verification|date=August 2021}} The Raptor design was refined, higher thrust versions. The initial 37 engines were reduced to 31 in 2020.{{cite tweet |last=Musk |first=Elon |author-link=Elon Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1256857873897803776 |date=3 May 2020 |title=@Kristennetten A little. Will have 31 engines, not 37, no big fins and legs similar to ship. That thrust dome is the super hard part. Raptor SL thrust starts at 200 ton, but upgrades in the works for 250 ton. |language=en |access-date=22 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210703081805/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1256857873897803776 |archive-date=3 July 2021 |url-status=live}} Musk stated that SpaceX would complete hundreds of cargo flights before carrying human passengers.{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/01/elon-musk-spacex-starship-to-fly-hundreds-of-missions-before-people.html |title=Elon Musk says SpaceX's Starship rocket will launch "hundreds of missions" before flying people |last=Sheetz|first=Michael |date=1 September 2020 |publisher=[[CNBC]] |access-date=7 February 2021 |archive-date=2 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200902190003/https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/01/elon-musk-spacex-starship-to-fly-hundreds-of-missions-before-people.html|url-status=live}} In April 2021, SpaceX publicly forecast that Earth to Earth passenger flights would be common within five years.{{cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=15 April 2021 |title=SpaceX adds to latest funding round |work=[[SpaceNews]] |url=https://spacenews.com/spacex-adds-to-latest-funding-round/ |access-date=15 April 2021}} === Low-altitude flights === {{Further|SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)#Starhopper|SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)#Hops (SN3 – SN6)}} [[File:Starship SN16.jpeg|thumb|alt=Panorama of stainless steel spacecraft|Leeward angle of Starship SN16 spacecraft|467x467px]] SpaceX was already constructing the first full-size ''[[Starship MK1|Starship Mk1]]'' and ''[[Starship MK2|Mk2]]'' upper-stage prototypes, at the SpaceX facilities in [[Boca Chica (Texas)|Boca Chica]], [[Texas]] and [[Cocoa, Florida]] respectively. Neither prototype flew: Mk1 was destroyed in November 2019 during a pressure [[stress testing|stress test]] and Mk2's Florida facility was abandoned and deconstructed throughout 2020.{{cite web |last=Grush |first=Loren |date=20 November 2019 |title=SpaceX's prototype Starship rocket partially bursts during testing in Texas |url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/20/20974884/spacex-starship-rocket-prototype-failure-test-texas |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211114163347/https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/20/20974884/spacex-starship-rocket-prototype-failure-test-texas |archive-date=14 November 2021 |access-date=16 December 2021 |work=[[The Verge]] |language=en}}{{cite web |last=Bergeron |first=Julia |date=6 April 2021 |title=New permits shed light on activity at SpaceX's Cidco and Roberts Road facilities |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/04/new-permits-spacex-cidco-roberts/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211206022611/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/04/new-permits-spacex-cidco-roberts/ |archive-date=6 December 2021 |access-date=3 January 2022 |work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |language=en-US}} After the Mk prototypes, SpaceX began naming its new Starship upper-stage prototypes with the prefix "SN", short for "[[serial number]]". No prototypes between [[Starship SN1|''SN1'']] and ''[[Starship SN4|SN4]]'' flew either—''SN1'' and ''[[Starship SN3|SN3]]'' collapsed during pressure stress tests, and SN4 exploded after its fifth engine firing.{{cite web |last1=Kanayama |first1=Lee |last2=Beil |first2=Adrian |date=28 August 2021 |title=SpaceX continues forward progress with Starship on Starhopper anniversary |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/08/starship-starhopper/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210831011318/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/08/starship-starhopper/ |archive-date=31 August 2021 |access-date=10 February 2022 |website=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |language=en-US}} In June 2020, SpaceX started constructing a launch pad for orbit-capable Starship rockets.{{cite web |last=Weber |first=Ryan|date=31 October 2021|title=Major elements of Starship Orbital Launch Pad in place as launch readiness draws nearer |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/10/starship-orbital-launch-pad/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211205163459/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/10/starship-orbital-launch-pad/|archive-date=5 December 2021|access-date=19 December 2021|work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]]|language=en-US}} The first flight-capable Starship SN5 was [[Cylinder|cylindrical]] as it had no flaps or nose cone: just one Raptor engine, [[fuel]] tanks, and a [[Boilerplate (spaceflight)|mass simulator]]. On 5 August 2020, SN5 performed a {{cvt|150|m|adj=on|sigfig=1}} high flight and successfully landed on a nearby pad.{{cite web|last=Mack |first=Eric|date=4 August 2020|title=SpaceX Starship prototype takes big step toward Mars with first tiny 'hop' |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/spacex-starship-prototype-takes-big-step-toward-mars-tuesday-with-first-hop/|url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211216161830/https://www.cnet.com/news/spacex-starship-prototype-takes-big-step-toward-mars-tuesday-with-first-hop/|archive-date=16 December 2021|access-date=16 December 2021|publisher=[[CNET]]|language=en}} On 3 September 2020, the similar-looking Starship SN6 repeated the hop;{{cite web|last=Sheetz|first=Michael|date=3 September 2020 |title=SpaceX launches and lands another Starship prototype, the second flight test in under a month |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/spacex-launches-and-lands-starship-sn6-prototype-in-flight-test.html|access-date=16 December 2021|publisher=[[CNBC]]|language=en |archive-date=16 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211216163834/https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/03/spacex-launches-and-lands-starship-sn6-prototype-in-flight-test.html|url-status=live}} later that month, the [[Raptor vacuum engine|Raptor Vacuum engine]] was fired in full duration at [[McGregor, Texas|McGregor.]]{{cite web |last=Kooser|first=Amanda|date=26 September 2020|title=Watch SpaceX fire up Starship's furious new Raptor Vacuum engine |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/watch-spacex-fire-up-furious-new-raptor-vacuum-engine-for-starship/|url-status=live |access-date=11 January 2022|publisher=[[CNET]]|language=en |archive-date=3 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210303064057/https://www.cnet.com/news/watch-spacex-fire-up-furious-new-raptor-vacuum-engine-for-starship/}} === High-altitude flights === {{Further|SpaceX Starship (spacecraft)#High-altitude test flights (SN8 – SN15)}} SN8 was the first fully complete Starship upper-stage prototype. It underwent four preliminary static fire tests between October and November 2020. On 9 December 2020, SN8 flew, slowly turning off its three engines one by one, and reached an altitude of {{cvt|12.5|km|sp=us}}. After SN8 dove back to the ground, its engines were hampered by low methane header tank pressure during the landing attempt, which led to a hard impact with the landing pad.{{cite web|last=Wattles|first=Jackie|date=10 December 2020|title=Space X's Mars prototype rocket exploded yesterday. Here's what happened on the flight|publisher=[[CNN]] |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/tech/spacex-starship-sn8-test-flight-recap-scn/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=10 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201210223909/https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/tech/spacex-starship-sn8-test-flight-recap-scn/index.html|archive-date=10 December 2020}} Because SpaceX had violated its [[launch license]] and ignored warnings of worsening [[shock wave]] damage, the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] investigated the incident for two months.{{cite web |last=Roulette |first=Joey |date=15 June 2021 |title=SpaceX ignored last-minute warnings from the FAA before December Starship launch |work=[[The Verge]] |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/15/22352366/elon-musk-spacex-faa-warnings-starship-sn8-launch-violation-texas |url-status=live |access-date=8 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211006042131/https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/15/22352366/elon-musk-spacex-faa-warnings-starship-sn8-launch-violation-texas |archive-date=6 October 2021}} On 2 February 2021, Starship SN9 launched to {{cvt|10|km|sp=us}} in a flight path similar to SN8. The prototype crashed upon landing because one engine did not ignite properly.{{cite web|last=Mack |first=Eric|date=2 February 2021|title=SpaceX Starship SN9 flies high, explodes on landing just like SN8 |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/spacex-starship-sn9-rocket-flies-high-explodes-on-landing-just-like-sn8/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210918040913/https://www.cnet.com/news/spacex-starship-sn9-rocket-flies-high-explodes-on-landing-just-like-sn8/|archive-date=18 September 2021 |access-date=17 December 2021|url-status=live|publisher=[[CNET]]|language=en}} A month later, on 3 March, ''[[Starship SN10]]'' launched on the same flight path as SN9. The vehicle landed hard and crushed its landing legs, leaning to one side. A fire was seen at the vehicle's base. It exploded less than ten minutes later,{{cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=5 May 2021 |title=Starship survives test flight |url=https://spacenews.com/starship-survives-test-flight/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220622063715/https://spacenews.com/starship-survives-test-flight/ |archive-date=22 June 2022 |access-date=22 June 2022 |website=[[SpaceNews]] |language=en-US}} probably due to a propellant tank rupture.{{cite web |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |date=3 March 2021 |title=SpaceX Mars Rocket Prototype Explodes, but This Time It Lands First |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/03/science/spacex-starship-launch-sn10.html |url-status=live |url-access=limited |access-date=19 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210605013824/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/03/science/spacex-starship-launch-sn10.html |archive-date=5 June 2021}} On 30 March, Starship SN11 flew into thick fog along the same flight path. The vehicle exploded during descent,{{cite web|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=30 March 2021|title=SpaceX Starship SN11 test flight flies high and explodes in the fog|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/spacex-starship-sn11-test-flight-flies-high-tuesday-then-explodes/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211220140407/https://www.cnet.com/news/spacex-starship-sn11-test-flight-flies-high-tuesday-then-explodes/|archive-date=20 December 2021|access-date=20 December 2021|url-status=live|publisher=[[CNET]] |language=en}} possibly due to excess propellant in a Raptor's methane turbopump.{{cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=6 April 2021 |title=Engine explosion blamed for latest Starship crash |url=https://spacenews.com/engine-explosion-blamed-for-latest-starship-crash/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929091019/https://spacenews.com/engine-explosion-blamed-for-latest-starship-crash/ |archive-date=29 September 2021 |access-date=22 June 2022 |website=[[SpaceNews]] |language=en-US}} In March 2021, the company disclosed a public construction plan for two [[Sub-orbital spaceflight|sub-orbital]] launch pads, two orbital launch pads, two landing pads, two test stands, and a large propellant tank farm. The company soon proposed developing the surrounding [[Boca Chica Village, Texas|Boca Chica village]] into a [[company town]] named [[SpaceX Starbase|Starbase]];{{cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=8 March 2021 |title=SpaceX reveals the great extent of its starport plans in South Texas |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/03/spacex-reveals-the-grand-extent-of-its-starport-plans-in-south-texas/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210921144725/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/03/spacex-reveals-the-grand-extent-of-its-starport-plans-in-south-texas/ |archive-date=21 September 2021 |access-date=17 December 2021 |work=[[Ars Technica]] |language=en-us}} locals raised concerns about SpaceX's authority, power, and a potential threat for eviction through [[eminent domain]].{{cite web |last1=Keates |first1=Nancy |last2=Maremont |first2=Mark |date=7 May 2021 |title=Elon Musk's SpaceX Is Buying Up a Texas Village. Homeowners Cry Foul. |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/elon-musk-spacex-rocket-boca-chica-texas-starbase-11620353687 |url-status=live |url-access=limited |access-date=17 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210507174246/https://www.wsj.com/articles/elon-musk-spacex-rocket-boca-chica-texas-starbase-11620353687 |archive-date=7 May 2021}} In early April, the orbital launch pad's fuel storage tanks began mounting. Starship prototypes SN12, SN13, and SN14 were scrapped before completion; [[Starship SN15|''SN15'']] was selected to fly instead.{{cite web |last=Mack |first=Eric |date=7 May 2021 |title=SpaceX's Mars prototype rocket, Starship SN15, might fly again soon |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/spacexs-mars-prototype-rocket-starship-sn15-might-fly-again-soon/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211220140406/https://www.cnet.com/news/spacexs-mars-prototype-rocket-starship-sn15-might-fly-again-soon/ |archive-date=20 December 2021 |access-date=20 December 2021 |publisher=[[CNET]] |language=en}} SN15 had better [[avionics]], structure, and upgraded engines. On 5 May 2021, ''SN15'' launched, completed the same maneuvers as older prototypes, and landed safely. Even though SN15, like SN10, had a small fire in the engine area after landing, it was extinguished, completing the first successful high-altitude test. According to a later report by SpaceX, SN15 experienced several issues while landing, including the loss of tank pressure and an engine.{{Cite web |date=29 March 2023 |title=Starbase Overview |url=https://www.spacex.com/vehicles/starship/assets/media/Starbase%20Overview.pdf |website=SpaceX |access-date=15 April 2023 |archive-date=4 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230404085552/https://www.spacex.com/vehicles/starship/assets/media/Starbase%20Overview.pdf |url-status=live }}{{Rp|page=2}} === Development towards first orbital launch === [[File:Starbase revisited (52125280262).jpg|alt=see caption|thumb|From left to right: [[Super Heavy B4|Booster 4]], [[Starship SN15|Ship 15]], [[Starship Ship 22|Ship 22]], and [[Starship Ship 20|Ship 20]] displayed at Starbase, June 2022]] In July 2021, [[Super Heavy BN3]] conducted its first full-duration static firing and lit three engines.{{cite web|last=Berger|first=Eric|date=23 July 2021|title=Rocket Report: Super Heavy lights up, China tries to recover a fairing|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/rocket-report-super-heavy-lights-up-china-tries-to-recover-a-fairing/|url-status=live|access-date=11 January 2022|website=[[Ars Technica]]|language=en-us|archive-date=12 August 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210812225543/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/rocket-report-super-heavy-lights-up-china-tries-to-recover-a-fairing/}} Around this time, SpaceX changed their naming scheme from "SN" to "Ship" for Starship crafts,{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=14 July 2021 |title=SpaceX will soon fire up its massive Super Heavy booster for the first time |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-will-soon-fire-up-its-massive-super-heavy-booster-for-the-first-time/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220108183113/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-will-soon-fire-up-its-massive-super-heavy-booster-for-the-first-time/ |archive-date=8 January 2022 |access-date=6 August 2022 |website=[[Ars Technica]] |language=en-us}} and from "BN" to "Booster" for [[SpaceX Super Heavy|Super Heavy boosters]].{{Cite web |last=Bergin |first=Chris |date=5 May 2022 |title=One year since SN15, Starbase lays groundwork for orbital attempt |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2022/05/one-year-since-sn15-starbase-lays-groundwork-for-orbital-attempt/ |access-date=6 August 2022 |website=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |language=en-US |archive-date=7 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220607232252/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2022/05/one-year-since-sn15-starbase-lays-groundwork-for-orbital-attempt/ |url-status=live }} A month later, using [[Crane (machine)|cranes]], Ship 20 was stacked atop Booster 4 to form the full launch vehicle for the first time; Ship 20 was also the first craft to have a body-tall heat shield.{{cite web|last=Sheetz|first=Michael|date=6 August 2021|title=Musk: 'Dream come true' to see fully stacked SpaceX Starship rocket during prep for orbital launch|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/06/elon-musk-spacex-starship-fully-stacked-is-dream-come-true.html|access-date=17 December 2021|publisher=[[CNBC]]|language=en|archive-date=19 August 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210819231115/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/06/elon-musk-spacex-starship-fully-stacked-is-dream-come-true.html|url-status=live}} In October 2021, the catching mechanical arms, also known as "chopsticks", were installed onto the integration tower and the first tank farm's construction was completed. Two weeks later, NASA and SpaceX announced plans to construct [[Kennedy Space Center]]'s Launch Complex 49.{{Cite press release|last=Costa|first=Jason|date=15 December 2021|title=NASA Conducts Environmental Assessment, Practices Responsible Growth|url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-conducts-environmental-assessment-practices-responsible-growth|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211216141738/https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-conducts-environmental-assessment-practices-responsible-growth/|archive-date=16 December 2021|access-date=16 December 2021|work=[[NASA]]}} After atmospheric descent tests in 2020-2021 SpaceX made Starship's [[body flaps]] narrower and lighter.{{cite tweet |last=Musk |first=Elon |author-link=Elon Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1418294282985906176 |date=22 July 2021 |title=@AlexSvanArt @Neopork85 Flight tests showed that we could make body flaps narrower & lighter |language=en |access-date=22 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210820124813/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1418294282985906176 |archive-date=20 August 2021 |url-status=live}} The public spotted the Raptor 2 engine at the start of 2022. Raptor 2 has a simpler design, less mass, wider throat, and an increase in central combustion chamber pressure from {{cvt|250|bar|psi}} to {{cvt|300|bar|psi}}. These changes yielded an increase in thrust from {{Cvt|1.85|MN|lbf|lk=in}} to {{Cvt|2.3|MN|lbf}}, but a decrease of 3 seconds (~0.9%) of [[specific impulse]].{{Cite web |last=Sesnic |first=Trevor |date=14 July 2022 |title=Raptor 1 vs Raptor 2: What did SpaceX change? |url=https://everydayastronaut.com/spacex-raptor-engine-comparison/ |access-date=21 August 2022 |website=[[The Everyday Astronaut]] |language=en-US |archive-date=19 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220819095907/https://everydayastronaut.com/spacex-raptor-engine-comparison/ |url-status=live }} In February 2022, after stacking Ship 20 on top of Booster 4 using mechanical arms, Elon Musk gave a presentation on Starship, Raptor engine and Florida spaceport development at Starbase.{{cite web |last1=Mooney |first1=Justin |last2=Bergin |first2=Chris |date=11 February 2022 |title=Musk outlines Starship progress towards self-sustaining Mars city |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2022/02/starships-self-sustaining-city-mars/ |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |language=en-US |archive-date=10 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220310040749/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2022/02/starships-self-sustaining-city-mars/ |url-status=live }} [[File:Starship and super heavy on their maiden flight.jpg|alt=ship 24 & booster 7 rising from a dark cloud|thumb|Ship 24 and Booster 7 lifting off of Launch Pad A in Starbase, April 2023|201x201px]] In June 2022, the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] determined that Starbase did not need a full [[environmental impact assessment]] but that SpaceX must address issues identified in the preliminary environmental assessment.{{cite web |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |date=13 June 2022 |title=SpaceX Wins Environmental Approval for Launch of Mars Rocket |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/13/science/spacex-starship-faa-review.html |url-status=live |url-access=limited |access-date=23 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220622043757/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/13/science/spacex-starship-faa-review.html |archive-date=22 June 2022}} In July, Booster 7 tested spinning the liquid oxygen [[turbopump]]s on all thirty-three Raptor engines. An explosion occurred at the vehicle's base, destroying a pressure pipe and causing minor damage to the launchpad.{{Cite web |last=Dvorsky |first=George |date=10 August 2022 |title=SpaceX Performs Limited Static Fire Test of Starship Booster, Avoids Explosion |url=https://gizmodo.com/spacex-avoids-explosion-in-test-of-starship-booster-1849395616 |access-date=18 September 2022 |website=[[Gizmodo]] |language=en-us |archive-date=20 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220920163714/https://gizmodo.com/spacex-avoids-explosion-in-test-of-starship-booster-1849395616 |url-status=live }} By the end of November, Ship 24 had performed 2- and full 6-engine static fires,{{Cite web |last1=Kshatriya |first1=Amit |last2=Kirasich |first2=Mark |date=31 October 2022 |title=Artemis I – IV Mission Overview / Status |url=https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/nac_october_2022_artemis_final_rev_b.pdf |website=NASA |publisher=Human Exploration and Operations Committee of the NASA Advisory Council |access-date=10 December 2022 |archive-date=3 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221103222633/https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/nac_october_2022_artemis_final_rev_b.pdf |url-status=live }}{{Rp|page=20}} while Booster 7 had performed static fires with 1, 3, 7, 14, 11 engines{{Cite web |last=Iemole |first=Anthony |date=7 December 2022 |title=Boosters 7 and 9 in dual flow toward Starbase test milestones |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2022/12/booster-7-9-flow-milestones/ |access-date=10 December 2022 |website=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |language=en-US |archive-date=10 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221210074352/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2022/12/booster-7-9-flow-milestones/ |url-status=live }}{{Rp|page=20}} and finally on 9 February 2023 a static fire with 31 engines at 50% throttle (33 was attempted but one engine was disabled pre-firing, and another engine aborted). In January 2023, Starship underwent a full [[wet dress rehearsal]] at Starbase, where it was filled with more than {{Cvt|10000000|lbs|t|order=flip}} of propellant.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=2023-01-24 |title=SpaceX completes Starship wet dress rehearsal |url=https://spacenews.com/spacex-completes-starship-wet-dress-rehearsal/ |access-date=2023-01-28 |website=SpaceNews |language=en-US |archive-date=15 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230415032641/https://spacenews.com/spacex-completes-starship-wet-dress-rehearsal/ |url-status=live }} === First attempted orbital test flight === {{Main|SpaceX Starship orbital test flight}} After a canceled launch attempt on 17 April 2023, due to a frozen valve,{{Cite web |last=Wall |first=Mike |date=2023-04-17 |title=SpaceX scrubs 1st space launch of giant Starship rocket due to fueling issue |url=https://www.space.com/spacex-scrubs-first-space-launch-starship |access-date=2023-04-20 |website=[[Space.com]] |language=en |archive-date=17 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230417165605/https://www.space.com/spacex-scrubs-first-space-launch-starship |url-status=live }} Booster 7 and Ship 24 lifted off on 20 April at 14:33 UTC in the first orbital flight test.{{cite web |last1=Wattles |first1=Jackie |last2=Strickland |first2=Ashley |date=2023-04-20 |title=SpaceX's Starship rocket lifts off for inaugural test flight, but explodes midair |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/04/20/world/spacex-starship-launch-thursday-scn/index.html |access-date=2023-04-20 |website=[[CNN]] |archive-date=21 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230421000659/https://www.cnn.com/2023/04/20/world/spacex-starship-launch-thursday-scn/index.html |url-status=live }} Because 3 engines were disabled prior to liftoff and several more shut down during the flight,{{Cite web |last=Bergin |first=Chris |date=2023-05-03 |title=Elon Musk pushes for orbital goal following data gathering objectives during Starship debut |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2023/05/musk-orbital-goal-starship-debut/ |access-date=2023-05-05 |website=NASASpaceFlight.com |language=en-US}} the vehicle reached only a maximum altitude of {{Cvt|39|km|mi|order=flip}}. The spacecraft also lost hydraulic control of the Raptor engines later in the flight, which led to multiple unplanned cartwheels. At around 3 minutes following liftoff, the rocket received a command to activate the automated [[Range safety|flight termination system]]. However, the flight termination system failed to destroy the vehicle, the vehicle tumbled for another 40 seconds, and finally exploded.{{Cite web |title=SpaceX |url=https://www.spacex.com/launches/mission/?missionId=starship-flight-test |access-date=2023-04-20 |website=SpaceX |language=en |archive-date=14 April 2023 2021|access-date=10 September 2021|work=[[SpaceX]]|type=PDF}}{{rp|2–4}} == Funding == As part of the [[Artemis HLS development history|Artemis HLS program]], SpaceX was awarded in April 2021 a $2.89
